asset_allocation_strategies.description: A long-term approach that maintains a fixed asset mix based on expected returns, risk tolerance, and time frame. Periodic rebalancing ensures alignment with investment goals.
asset_allocation_strategies.example: A portfolio with 50% stocks and 50% bonds expecting an average return of 7.5% per year.

asset_allocation_strategies.description: A strategy that involves continuous rebalancing by purchasing assets that decline in value and selling assets that increase in value to maintain the original asset mix.
asset_allocation_strategies.rule_of_thumb: Rebalance when any asset class moves more than 5% from its original allocation.

asset_allocation_strategies.description: A flexible strategy that temporarily adjusts the asset mix to capitalize on short-term investment opportunities while maintaining a long-term allocation plan.
asset_allocation_strategies.key_factor: Requires market-timing skills and discipline to return to the strategic asset mix after achieving short-term gains.

asset_allocation_strategies.description: An active strategy that continuously adjusts the asset mix in response to market trends, selling declining assets and purchasing rising ones.
asset_allocation_strategies.key_difference: Unlike constant-weighting allocation, this strategy follows market momentum rather than maintaining a fixed allocation.

asset_allocation_strategies.description: A risk-averse strategy that establishes a base portfolio value, below which investments are shifted to risk-free assets such as Treasury bills.
asset_allocation_strategies.example: If the portfolio falls to the base value, funds are moved into secure investments to preserve capital.

asset_allocation_strategies.description: A comprehensive approach that combines economic expectations with an investor's risk tolerance to create a balanced asset mix.
asset_allocation_strategies.key_feature: Unlike other strategies, it accounts for both market changes and personal risk preferences.
